top_categories.workout_context: Big Sugar Gravel’s ozark gravel, punchy climbs demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Racing Big Sugar Gravel isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
Big Sugar Gravel rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
At 100 miles, Big Sugar Gravel punishes athletes who haven’t trained their body to produce power when glycogen runs low.
Big Sugar Gravel’s ozark mountain gravel with punchy repeated climbs and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at Big Sugar Gravel when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at Big Sugar Gravel — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of Big Sugar Gravel. Make this intensity feel like home.
Short, violent efforts are unavoidable at Big Sugar Gravel — climbs demanding 2-minute maximal efforts, surges to close gaps, attacks on ozark mountain gravel with punchy repeated climbs.
Big Sugar Gravel’s 9,500ft of climbing demands seated and standing versatility — the ability to change climbing style as gradient and fatigue dictate.
Blended sessions combine endurance with intensity spikes — exactly what Big Sugar Gravel’s ozark mountain gravel with punchy repeated climbs delivers on race day.
Every session at Big Sugar Gravel intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for Big Sugar Gravel’s 100 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at Big Sugar Gravel demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride ozark mountain gravel with punchy repeated climbs at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: ozark gravel, punchy climbs, technical descents. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 100 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Gravel Specific, Race Simulation, and TT Threshold to prepare you for 100 miles of ozark mountain gravel with punchy repeated climbs in Bentonville, Arkansas.
